bibl.title: Letter from Lindsley Arthur to Henry Rose Carter, April 11, 1923

div1.p: Arthur poses numerous questions related to mosquitos.

div1.head: Letter from Lindsley Arthur to Henry Rose Carter, April 11, 1923
div1.opener:
JAMES A. HAYNE, M.D.
Secretary and State Health Officer
L. M. FISHER
Associate Sanitary Engineer
U.S. Public Health Service
In Charge Malaria Co-operative Work
State Board of Health
of South Carolina
DIVISION MALARIA CO-OPERATIVE WORK
P.O. Box 358, Georgetown, S.C.
Columbia
April 11, 1923
Dr.H.R. Carter, Sen. Surg.
U.S. Public Health Service
Washington, D.C.
Honorable Sir,
div1.p:
In January, 1923, a county control unit was estab-
lished in Georgetown County, South Carolina in co-operation with
the State Board of Health, International Health Board, U.S.P.H.S.,
and Georgetown County. A malaria field agent was placed in charge
of the operations in malaria control, I am the agent and am writing
you for certain information.

The work at present is educational activities, to which
success is accredited, the use of the school primer, 'Malaria-Its Cause
and Prevention'; as you are the author, I wish to mention the most
valuable services of this bulletin-better said, we couldn't get a-
long without it.

1. In the primer you spoke of certain plants which attack-
ed the life of the adult anopheles. As you are familiar with the cli-
mate of the South Carolina littoral, would you give me a discussion
of these plants as they may be used in planting around homes. The
Civic League of the port city of Georgetown is giving the department
here their co-operation and aid, and at this time when house-wives
are giving their attention to planting their flowers, this inform-
ation would be very valuable.

2. In the use of the Quinine Prophylaxis, there is one
thing of immediate concern- What treatment to be used to the best
advantage in case there is a case which has idiosyncracies in the
taking of the quinine? There are numbers of people here in the county
who can not take quinine because of the oppression which develops
after a very small dose. Will you explain to me probable causes for
this and and its proper treatment?

3. Will you explain the feeding or sustenance of the anoph-
eline male, and is this true of the “Stegomyia” and “Culex”?

4. Is there a reason for the why the culex are not carriers
of the parasite- man-to-man?

5. As hemoglobinuric fever is quite prevalent in this section,
will you give me a discussion of this phase of its cause and preven-
tion?

Some of these questions may appear trivial but I am anxious
to have a full treatise of them, because each one has a marked impor-
tance in this section of South Carolina. In making my census thruout
the county I wish to be well posted, so my census will be as near
accurate as possible as there is no time to be taken in connection
with blood index work - of course, in a general application.

I hope that my letter finds you in good health and with
my kindest regards, I am

closer.signed:
Lindsley Arthur
(Malaria Field Agent)
Georgetown County Malarial Control
